text: every single one of us understands what
empathy is on a personal level and
that's because we are blessed with the
ability to connect with other people
right we're born with this biological um
Power to connect with other folks to
step outside of ourselves and walk in
someone else's shoes to intuitively get
where that person is coming from and and
get their their feelings and their point
of view um for an organization having a
widespread sense of empathy is to get
every single person in that organization
to have an intuitive sense of the people
beyond their walls for the the folks who
buy our products and services um and who
ultimately fund our 401ks you know the
people who actually have a stake in our
success and so we can get you know not
just the people in market research or
marketing but the people in R&D and
finance and HR and IT and legal
everybody in a company to have that kind
of gut sense intuition for ordinary
people what we find is the companies do
better as a result the real power of
empathy and it's something that
surprised us when we started looking at
the topic was yes empathy will allow you
to know things in your gut before the
rest of us read about it in the Wall
Street Journal and yes it'll give you
the courage of your convictions to act
on something and take a risk on
something new but the big surprise for
us was how much that sense of empathy
for the world around around you um gives
people something that companies struggle
with which is to give their folks a
sense of Mission to give people a reason
to come into work every day and we've
seen this over and over again that when
you when you connect with the outside
world you suddenly realize that wow
there's all these people out there who
are counting on me counting on me to do
the right thing right and so you start
to see your business in a completely
different way uh you know Target is a
great example of this where over the
last 10 years they have stopped
competing with Walmart to shave a half a
cent off the cost of a bottle of
detergent they are actually creating a
community and they're creating a place
where people love to go hang out we've
seen um moms who leave their kids at
home with their husbands and have a
girls night out on a Friday night and
they go shop at Target together and
we've seen dads on a Saturday afternoon
who you know are with their kids and
they don't know where to take them and
there isn't a park nearby so they go
hang out and
Target in many ways the big reset that
we're going through is kind of like a
Back to the Future it's going back to
the way that uh companies used to do
business but there was a time when
people bought things that they needed
right from companies that made things
that had value right um and what's
happened is we've kind of let go of that
as things have gotten more and more
abstract right uh you know the financial
service industry is is poster child you
know for this but I'm seeing a
fundamental change and it's getting back
to saying you know we need a gut level
intuition and an empathy for people
right so that we can actually solve
their problems because that's worth
paying for uh you know I I'll give you
one example which is not in the
book you know I I get called into to
talk about innovation in companies and I
often say okay well that's great but I
want to come in and talk about empathy
and they're often a little bit leery
because they're like hold on that
empathy stuff sounds very touchy feely
you know we're IBM or we're GE we don't
talk about that we talk about you know
you want to talk about innovation that's
great and so I have to spend half an
hour on the phone convincing them no
this is important empathy is the key to
Innovation and I remember I was giving a
talk at GE to 300 marketing managers and
we were talking about uh you know why
empathy matters and how it's actually
the way that you can drive growth and at
the end of the conversation as I I was
leaving the building two guys came up to
me and each of them had worked at GE for
over 30 years each right so these are
people who had worked at GE their entire
adult life
and they told me and said you know what
you're absolutely right empathy is what
we need around here we need that gut
sense and we need to get back to that
and you know what that's how we used to
do business before Jack Welsh and we've
just been pushing the money around ever
since so it gives me hope for GE because
it tells me there's something deeper in
the DNA there than just following a
stock price but it also tells me that
maybe we've gotten away from that in the
last few years that we're doing things
that are good for the bottom line today
this week weak rather than what's good
for the company and its shareholders and
its customers over the long
term when I wrote the book I was
primarily focused on on the business
situation because I was looking at how
companies can grow and prosper and it
seemed that empathy was the biggest
differentiator um but you know what I've
been most surprised about is how much
empathy is is become a a larger Trend
something that is being focused on at
the highest levels of government even uh
Barack Obama has become our chief
empathy officer for the country um and
i' it's just been amazing to see when he
was at um the Saddleback Ranch last year
and and Rick Warren asked him why do you

said that he was looking for someone who

kind of flipped out on both sides of the

what is empathy a good thing is it a bad

that oh by empathy he means we want

it seems like empathy has gotten a bad
rap over the last 50 years in America
we've kind of confused it with being

ability to connect with other people and

he's one of
us creating new markets comes from

it's about having a fundamentally

that makes you think wow I thought the

different change you know in in wired to
care I write about one of my students
and those kind of reframes and they're
incredibly powerful when you get a

suddenly the world is all numbers and
you can't go back to the view that you
had before I had a student um a couple

right and and so we we had you know 50
of America's best and brightest right
these are all Stanford students and
they're studying how do old people clean
and how do young people clean and how do
Latinos clean and in the final
presentation um they were doing a

was up there and he was presenting how
young people clean you know what the
world of an 18-year-old looks like which
is not a pretty picture when it comes to
cleaning and he's presenting out uh you
know his story and he's showing video
and this vice president from Clorox kind
of cuts him off right in the middle and
says wait a minute it sounds like you're
telling me that people your age don't
care about cleaning nearly as much as
people my age and we should forget about
you and this guy says no that's not what
I'm saying I'm saying that people have
come to view the world through some
basic frames based on whatever they've
experienced in their life and some
people who for whatever they experienced
earlier on view all of the world around
them as being made up of durable goods
that the stuff around you will last a
table a chair you take care of it you
keep it looking like new because it'll
be with you for a long time and there's
other people who view all of these same
things as disposable Goods so if you get
a scratch in a table it's no big deal
you throw it out and you get a new table
right so there are people with a durable
good mentality and people with a
disposable good mentality and people who
are the age of this vice president
resident tend to view the world as being
made up of durable things things that
last and people who are 17 or 18 years

on their third personal computer by the

cell phone and they say things to their
parents like Mom can we get a new car
this one has a rattle in it I mean
that's how they view the world and then
the student of mine kind of looked at
the VP and said here's the real Clincher
everything that Clorox makes everything
that you produce speaks to the world as
if it was dur durble it says keep it
looking like new keep it looking like
the day you bought it and you have an
entire generation of people coming up
who think well why would I do that why
wouldn't I just throw it out and get a
new one and this is a fundamental
problem it's also a fundamental reframe
you know for this vice president if you
think about it she walked into the room
thinking that her business was about you
know having a nice lemon scent and you
know killing bacteria and maybe cutting
cleaning time in half and here were some

that's all great but it is totally
irrelevant to an entire group of people
because they see the world in a
different
way we buy things for wildly different
reasons we buy things because they
satisfy basic needs like hunger right or
thirst uh we we we buy products because
they make us feel good they they meet
our needs of identity or or needs of
belonging right on some level though we
buy everything because it meets some
needs that we have and I think companies
have kind of gotten shy about the the
reasons why people buy their products
the biggest myth I have heard in
Corporate America is the myth of the low
interest category you'll go into a

say oh well it's a relatively low
interest category it's something that
people aren't that interested in and so
well our biggest you know our only
choice is to just slice it down and make

that's true I don't think there is any
such thing as a low interest interest
category every time we go in and you
know we study cleaning products and we

soft drinks and we realize it's much
more about kind of feeling like you have
a sense of identity and a belonging with
you know with a group of people um we
study you know engineering
thermoplastics and we discover that it's

those thermoplastics feeling like
they're competent in their job there's
always a human being in a high interest
Factor associated with it I I've told
more than one uh you know CEO that the
first first thing he needed to do was to

do you think we have a low interest
product okay you're fired right and get
rid of people who don't believe that the

because it is changing the world whether
they're noticing it or
not if I ever had a really bad boss the
only person I could point to is myself
um I've been a lousy boss for myself um
just because I I find that I'm spending

and I'm probably not spending enough

our
life when I was working in India um I

we ever got the thing to be TR
waterproof it was supposed to sell in

played out as a big lesson today in

this was not the right product to to be

with is even
harder you need to find a model of

Proctor Gamble and IBM realize that what

they are doing something that plays to

they're actually setting themselves up

competitor's strengths right so the key
thing isn't about doing open Innovation

Innovation it's about playing to your

already do great and doing more of it
and less of the stuff that you do
poorly Wikipedia is great because number
one it's the it's the you know it's the

it's like well let's go actually look
